title: 106_hr2555
content: The Act titled "Genetic Privacy and Nondiscrimination Act of 1999" prohibits health insurance discrimination based on genetic information. The Genetic Privacy and Nondiscrimination Act of 1999 includes amendments to the Public Health Service Act regarding genetic testing nondiscrimination requirements and prohibitions against the use and disclosure of genetic information. The Genetic Privacy and Nondiscrimination Act of 1999 prohibits group health plans and health insurance issuers from using genetic information to affect benefits or disclose genetic information without consent. The Genetic Privacy and Nondiscrimination Act of 1999 prohibits the disclosure of genetic information without authorization, except in certain circumstances such as criminal investigations. The Genetic Privacy and Nondiscrimination Act of 1999 prohibits the disclosure of genetic information without authorization, except in specific circumstances like criminal investigations, court orders, paternity establishment, or body identification purposes. The prohibitions also apply to any redisclosure of genetic information by entities. The Genetic Privacy and Nondiscrimination Act of 1999 defines genetic information as details about an individual's genes, family genes, gene products, or inherited characteristics. It also defines a genetic test as a method to determine genetic traits using DNA, RNA, chromosomes, or proteins. The Genetic Privacy and Nondiscrimination Act of 1999 defines genetic information and genetic tests. Section 2723(c) of the Act is amended to include sections 2704 and 2707. ERISA amendments include nondiscrimination requirements for genetic testing and prohibition against the use and disclosure of genetic information. In addition, a new section 2753 is added to the Public Health Service Act, prohibiting the use and disclosure of genetic information in individual health insurance. The provisions of section 2707 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. The Department of Veterans' Affairs will prescribe standards for the use and disclosure of genetic information in connection with hospital care and medical services. The Department of Veterans' Affairs will prescribe standards for the use and disclosure of genetic information in connection with benefits provided by group health plans and health insurance coverage. The amendments regarding the treatment of genetic information have specific effective dates for group health plans, health insurance coverage in the individual market, and hospital care and medical services. Additionally, there is a prohibition of employment practices involving genetic information. It is unlawful for an employer to acquire or use genetic information of an employee or applicant for employment, or require a genetic test for discriminatory purposes in connection with employment matters. It is unlawful for an employer to disclose genetic information of employees to unauthorized individuals or maintain access to such information without a job-related or legal necessity. Employers are prohibited from accessing an employee's genetic information without their prior written consent. The enforcement of this rule falls under the powers, remedies, and procedures outlined in the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The section provides powers, remedies, and procedures for individuals alleging a violation related to employment or employment opportunities, including genetic information. Definitions for employer, employee, and genetic information are outlined in the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Genetic test refers to a test to determine genetic characteristics in an individual, including DNA, RNA, chromosomes, or proteins. Other terms such as group health plan, health insurance issuer, and health insurance coverage are defined in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 defines terms like "employee welfare benefit plan" and "participant" according to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The National Bioethics Advisory Commission must provide recommendations on DNA sample protection and genetic information standards to Congress within a year of this Act's enactment. This includes standards for collection, storage, use of DNA samples, and genetic information, as well as acquisition and retention of genetic information in all settings with appropriate exceptions.
